comments:

Exception when starting bundle:  org.eclipse.soda.sat.core
org.osgi.framework.BundleException: Exception in org.eclipse.soda.sat.core.internal.framework.bundle.Activator.start() of bundle org.eclipse.soda.sat.core.

When this exception occurs, the SAT core bundle will not start automatically. This is not good since practically all of our other bundles have dependencies on this bundle. If you attempt to start the bundle manually, the system will hang for several minutes but eventually recover. Once the SAT bundle has been manually started, as far as we can tell, things work normally. This defect is reproducible but not reliable. We have seen it occur on Windows and Linux.
Tried to attach a log file to this defect but kept getting an error page claiming that some sort of perl script error occurred. I'm pasting some of its contents here to provide context for the exception.

Looking at BundleDependencyManager is see the following.  I have marked line 470, which is where the problem starts.

private boolean registerImportedPackageDependency(String packageName,
    Bundle importer) {
  PackageAdmin admin = getPackageAdmin();
  ExportedPackage[] exportedPackages = admin.getExportedPackages(packageName);
  if (exportedPackages == null) return false;  // Early return.

  for (int i = 0; i < exportedPackages.length; i++) {
    ExportedPackage exportedPackage = exportedPackages [ i ];
    Bundle[] importingBundles = exportedPackage.getImportingBundles(); // 470
    ...
  }
}

The NPE is on line 470, meaning that it has to be exportedPackage that is null.  I'm getting the exported packages by calling getExportedPackages(String) on PackageAdmin.  Looking at the OSGi's PackageAdmin documentation I see the following Javadoc for getExportedPackages(String):

/**
 * Gets the exported packages for the specified package name.
 * 
 * @param name The name of the exported packages to be returned.
 * 
 * @return An array of the exported packages, or <code>null</code> if no
 *         exported packages with the specified name exists.
 * @since 1.2
 */
public ExportedPackage[] getExportedPackages(String name);


This is very curious, since I am checking for null, but it appears that I am getting an array back, but that the array contains null as one or more of its elements.  This sounds like a PackageAdmin bug, but I cannot be sure without reproducing this under the debugger.

John: How easy is it to reproduce this problem?  If you can reproduce it, can you please do so under the control of the debugger so that you can tell me what is getting returned from getExportedPackages(String).



I think that this is really an Equinox bug in PackageAdmin, but I need to investigate further.  For now I am going to patch SAT to work around the null, as follows:

  for (int i = 0; i < exportedPackages.length; i++) {
    ExportedPackage exportedPackage = exportedPackages [ i ];
    if (exportedPackage == null) continue;  // Skip to next iteration.
    Bundle[] importingBundles = exportedPackage.getImportingBundles(); // 470
    ...
  }
After looking at this a second time, and discussing it with Dave, it is clear that this problem is not something I can fix.  My previous change is invalid, and the best I can do is add a try/catch to prevent the NPE in Equinox from hurting SAT.  I am catching the exception and logging it, just so we can see the problem happening still... I really don't want to mask it totally.

for (int i = 0; i < exportedPackages.length; i++) {
  ExportedPackage exportedPackage = exportedPackages [ i ];
  try {
    Bundle[] importingBundles = exportedPackage.getImportingBundles();
	
    if (importingBundles != null) {
      for (int j = 0; j < importingBundles.length; j++) {
        Bundle importingBundle = importingBundles [ j ];
        boolean match = importingBundle.equals(importer);
        if (match == false) continue;  // Skip to next iteration.
        Bundle exporter = exportedPackage.getExportingBundle();
        if (exporter == null) continue;
        register(importer, exporter);
        return true;  // Early return.
      }
    }
  } catch (Exception exception) {
    String message = exception.getMessage();
    LogUtility.logDebug(message, exception);
  }
Since I believe that this is an Equniox bug, I have filed bug 176782 rather than moving this one over.  I am going to close this one as INVALID, since it is not technically an SAT bug.
